posts.name: Alewife
posts.note: Stylish gastropub featuring updated American fare and many craft beers in a re-imagined 1800s bank. You need to order the wild boar sliders or duck fat fries with porky belly on top.

posts.name: Baltimore Farmers' Market and Bazaar
posts.add1: E Saratoga St and Holliday St
posts.note: NOTE - Only open Sunday from mid-April to Mid-Deceber. While strolling through Maryland's largest producers-only market (producers-only meaning all vendors make what they sell), shoppers can revel at the sight of a vast quantity of foods, including crisp seasonal fruits and vegetables, poultry, seafood, beef, pork, lamb, rabbit, fresh baked goods, flavorful herbs and organically raised and produced milk, yogurt, butter, eggs and cheese products. Additionally, dozens of food vendors add spice to the market with multicultural cuisine such as popular pit beef sandwiches, omelets and breakfast burritos, crepes, wood fired pizzas, pies and quiches, soups, noodles and dumplings. If you like fresh horse radish find the guy near the information both it will clean out your sinuses it's that strong.

posts.name: Bar Clavel
posts.note: Mexican-inspired cocktails and elevated cuisine are served in a simple room with hip hanging lights.

posts.name: Bertha's Mussels
posts.note: Quirky seafood joint and tavern since 1972, known for mussels and regularly scheduled live music.

posts.name: Blue Moon Cafe
posts.note: Popular cafe serving American breakfast meals in a bright, funky setting, open 24 hours on weekends. The dish to get is the Captain Crunch French Toast with homemade whipcream and fresh seasonal berries. Their cheese omelette, home fires, and toast is great too. Plus, if your still hungry see if you can get yourself one of their huge cinnamon rolls.

posts.name: The Bun Shop
posts.note: Loftlike, late-night cafe for filled buns like piroshki and empanadas, plus Vietnamese coffee. BYOB.

posts.name: Chaps Pit Beef
posts.note: Popular pit-beef outlet serving namesake sandwiches and homestyle sides in a strip-club parking lot. You need to order the 'Habbit', which has smoked roast beef, smoked turkey and smoked ham, along with cheese and a side of French fries.
posts.cptn: Cross section of the 'Habbit', which has smoked roast beef, smoked turkey and smoked ham, along with cheese and a side of French fries

posts.name: The Charmery
posts.note: Quirky, family-owned ice cream shop offering innovative and seasonal flavors in a cheery space.

posts.name: G & A Restaurant
posts.note: Iconic diner known for hot dogs, burgers and other casual eats served in classic digs with a cxounter.

posts.name: Golden West Cafe
posts.note: Funky Hampden roadhouse offering New Mexican dishes and eclectic comfort grub in unpretentious digs. The one item that has never steered me wrong is the Huevos Montulenos, which is whole kernel corn cakes topped with two sunny-up eggs, pinto -or- black beans, green -or- red chile sauce, feta cheese, salsa fresca, fried banana and a flour tortilla.

posts.name: Maggie's Farm
posts.note: Intimate bar and restaurant showcasing thoughtfully sourced, globally inspired provisions and cocktails.

posts.name: The Mushroom Stand
posts.add1: E Saratoga St and Holliday St
posts.note: You need to order the King Oyster Mushroom Fritters with fresh feta and some hot sauce with salad greens. The were worth the wait. They only sell 200 orders and when there gone there gone. Their grilled/roasted portabella mushroom sandwich or salad looked great too while waiting for my food.

posts.name: One-Eyed Mike's
posts.note: Local gastropub in a historic former tavern with a hand-carved bar, tin ceiling and courtyard. If they have cioppino which is a seafood stew if it's on special you need to order it.

posts.name: Woodberry Kitchen
posts.note: Old factory turned hip, rustic-chic place for refined New American fare with a farm-to-table bent.
